instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01814: What is 820-01814? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.PP1V8_SSD0: What is PP1V8_SSD0? PP1V8_SSD0 is a power rail responsible for powering the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on newer Macbook Pros.
definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
Board came with significant liquid damage around one USB-C connector and the NAND power circuitry around <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>. Found <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> shorted to ground, which I fixed by removing shorted <CAPACITOR>C9073</CAPACITOR> (<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_SSD0</SIGNAL>). Board then briefly produced 20V but is now stuck at 5V.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0V  diode mode 0.42V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_T</SIGNAL>: 0V  diode mode 0.43V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL>: 0V  diode mode 0.42V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>: 5.2V
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AUX_DET</SIGNAL>: 1.29V
<SIGNAL>CHGR_VDDA</SIGNAL>: 5.1V
<SIGNAL>CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL>: 5.1V
The 3.3V and 1.8V LDOs are present on <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>

On this board, PPBUS is generated before PP3V3, correct?

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> comes from <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> as in any T2 board.
So you need to get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> first.

I suspect more corrosion damage on USB-C area.
Do you get 1V1 LDO, when power corresponding port?

Be sure to use original 87/96W charger.
Check if board has activity with a good battery.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
I do not get the 1V1 LDO on the plugged-in port. I only see 3V3 and 1V8 LDOs on each plugged-in port. 

I checked the CC lines and there are no shorts to ground.

The battery is empty - waiting for a good original battery to arrive.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
Check TBT ROMs and their traces.
You can try reflashing with known good dump.
Dont forget to make backup.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
TBT ROMs <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and UB090 look fine. However, they are powered by two 3V3 LDO rails, which are not always present on this board. Shouldn't <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL> be present no matter which USB-C port is plugged in? I only get 3V3 LDO on the one plugged-in port, not all four CD3215s. 

Seems like the CD3215s are not talking to each other. What could that indicate?

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message: Check <SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL> signals.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message: <SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL> are 0V.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message: Ok, so I need to figure out why <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is not producing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. What are the typical culprits on a T2 machine?

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> should generate (initial) <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> without T2 communication.
Once T2 starts, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is adjusted to final value.
Try changing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>...

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message: Apparently, it's not easy to find the ISL9240HI for this machine. Will need to order some reballed chips from donor boards...

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
You were dead right: replacing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> (<CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP>) restored PPBUS (12.6V), <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> (3.4V), and 20V on the charger.

Now on to the rest of the board.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message: What is the actual behavior?

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message: I'm just getting started with T2 boards and their architecture; can you point me to a post or page explaining basic troubleshooting? A bit confusing with the new SoC, PMU, and T2 chips...

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
Power on sequence available only for 01055 and 01598.
None of them help too much for T2 boards in general.

Check voltage on the big coils.
SSD and G3S voltages must come before S5 state.

Is the machine recognized in DFU mode?

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
Yes, board enters DFU mode.

I just found another corrosion-related short in <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>, one of the power supplies for the SSD. I removed <CHIP>U9080</CHIP>, waiting for replacement chip. So with the SSD nonfunctional it’s pointless to troubleshoot other power rails?

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
SSD voltages must come before achieve S5 state even.
Be sure no short on the NANDs power rails.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
After <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> replacement, all NAND power have been restored, although I'm worried about the low resistances on some of these lines. Can you confirm that these are right? I don't have another board to compare.

<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>: 2.5V  240Ω
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0</SIGNAL>: 1.8V   5.2kΩ
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL>: 0.9V  137Ω

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
Ohm scale is not a proper test for high resistances.
Use diode mode, as should be.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>: 0.20
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0</SIGNAL>: 0.35
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL>: 0.34

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
Compare SSD0/1 values; should get very similar values.
I don't have comparison board here.
Also look at logi.wiki web page; they have diode mode readings for several boards.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
Ok, I confirmed that on a good <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board, the three NAND rail resistances are very similar, so all good here.

Now, when I plug in a charger, I get:
PPBUS: 12.6V
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>: 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL>: 5.1V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>: 5.1V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL>: 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 0V

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground on all big coils.
Compare with good board.

Can you complete DFU, or get error?

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message: DFU Restore repeatedly fails with the error below.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 2019 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V USB-C
threads.message: SSD may got damaged, even no low resistance detected on its power rails...
